description: From Middle English lok, from Old English loc, from Proto-West Germanic *lok, from Proto-Germanic *lukƒÖ from Proto-Indo-European *lewg- (‚Äúto bend; turn‚Äù). The verb is from Middle English locken, lokken, louken, from Old English l≈´can, Proto-West Germanic *l≈´kan, from Proto-Germanic *l≈´kanƒÖ. Related to luxe via Latin.

entries.meaning: Something used for fastening, which can only be opened with a key or combination.
(computing, by extension) A mutex or other token restricting access to a resource.
A segment of a canal or other waterway enclosed by gates, used for raising and lowering boats between levels.
examples: Here the canal came to a check, ending abruptly with a large lock.

entries.meaning: (firearms) The firing mechanism.
Complete control over a situation.
examples: Even though he had not yet done so, Jack felt he had a lock on the game.

entries.meaning: Something sure to be a success.
examples: Brian thinks she's a lock to get a scholarship somewhere.

entries.meaning: (rugby) A player in the scrum behind the front row, usually the tallest members of the team.
A fastening together or interlacing; a closing of one thing upon another; a state of being fixed or immovable.
examples: Albemarle Street closed by a lock of carriages

entries.meaning: A place impossible to get out of, as by a lock.
A device for keeping a wheel from turning.
A grapple in wrestling.
examples: They must be also practis'd in all the Locks and Gripes of Wrestling

verbs.description: lock (third-person singular simple present locks, present participle locking, simple past locked, past participle locked or (obsolete) locken)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become fastened in place.
examples: If you put the brakes on too hard, the wheels will lock.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fasten with a lock.
examples: Remember to lock the door when you leave.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be capable of becoming fastened in place.
examples: This door locks with a key.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To intertwine or dovetail.
examples: with his hands locked behind his back
We locked arms and stepped out into the night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, break dancing) To freeze one's body or a part thereof in place.
To furnish (a canal) with locks.
To raise or lower (a boat) in a lock.
To seize (e.g. the sword arm of an antagonist) by turning one's left arm around it, to disarm them.
(Internet, transitive) To modify (a thread) so that users cannot make new posts in it.
(Internet, transitive, Wikimedia jargon) To prevent a page from being edited by other users.
examples: Frequently-vandalized pages are generally locked to prevent further damage.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, rugby) To play in the position of lock.

description: From Middle English lok, lokke, from Old English locc (‚Äúhair of the head, hair, lock of hair, curl, ringlet‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *lokk, from Proto-Germanic *lukkaz, from Proto-Indo-European *lugn√≥-, from Proto-Indo-European *lewg- (‚Äúto bend‚Äù).

Cognate with West Frisian lok, lokke, Dutch lok (‚Äúearlock, curl‚Äù), German Locke (‚Äúlock of hair, curl‚Äù), Danish lok, Swedish lock (‚Äúlock of hair, curl‚Äù). It has been theorised that the word may be related to the Gothic verb *êåªêåøêå∫êå∞êåΩ (*lukan, ‚Äúto shut‚Äù) in its ancient meaning "to curb".

entries.meaning: A tuft or length of hair, wool, etc.
A small quantity of straw etc.
(Scotland, law, historical) A quantity of meal, the perquisite of a mill-servant.
